lines.text:
[singing]
When you walk through a storm / Hold your head up high / And don't be afraid of the dark.
[Upon hearing that Billy will be a father]
My mother had a baby once.

[trying to seduce Carrie Pipperidge]
Oh, Miss Pipperidge, I'm just crazy fer you! Why. just to see your lovely smile I'd swim through beer with my mouth closed!

[singing]
Longing to tell you, but afraid and shy / I let my golden chances pass me by. / Now, I've lost you / Soon I will go in the mist of day / And you never will know / How I loved you / How I loved you.
[last lines]

[at Louise's graduation ceremony]
It's the custom at these graduations to pick out some old duck like me to preach at the kids. Well, I can't preach at you. I know you all too well. I brought most of you into the world, rubbed linament on your backs, poured castor oil down your throats. I only hope that now I got you this far that you'll turn out to be worth all the trouble I took with you. I - I can't tell you any sure way to happiness. I only know that you've gotta go out and find it for yourselves. You can't lean on the success of your parents. That's their success. And don't be held back by their failures.

[to Louise]
Listen to him. Believe him.
"When you walk through a storm, hold your head up high." You know that one?

[singing]
And don't be afraid of the dark.
[they continue with the rest of the song]

[to Louise, as the singing is still going on]
Believe him, darling. Believe.
[Louise joins in the singing, and puts her arm around the girl sitting next to her, who reciprocates]

[Walks over to Julie]
I loved you, Julie. Know that I loved you.

[Julie smiles and joins in singing. As the song reaches its climax, Billy and the Heavenly Friend walk away from the graduation and up a hill. Billy then takes a last look toward the schoolyard and follows the Heavenly Friend]

[singing]
Walk on, walk on, with hope in your heart/ And you'll never walk alone,/ You'll never walk alone!

[singing]
And, what's the use of wonderin' / If the endin' will be sad? / He's your feller and you love him / There's nothin' more to say.
I didn't make it up, Mother. Honest, there was a strange man here, and he hit me hard. I heard the sound of it, Mother, but it didn't hurt. It didn't hurt at all. It was just as if he kissed my hand.
Go into the house, Louise.
What's happened, Mother? Don't you believe me?
I believe you.
Then why don't you tell me why you're actin' so funny?
It's nothin', darlin'.
But is it possible, Mother, for someone to hit you hard like that - real loud and hard, and it not hurt you at all?
It is possible dear, for someone to hit you, hit you hard, and it not hurt at all.
[they embrace]
I just couldn't get the hang of being married.
Was that Julie's fault?
No, but maybe it wasn't my fault either.

[to the Heavenly Friend]
Well, now ain't that just dandy! Here you take the trouble to tell me there's trouble down there but you don't even know what kind of trouble it is!
Simmer down now, Billy; you're forgettin' - here there *is* no time; this is the beginning and the end.

[singing]
When I marry Mister Snow / The flowers will be buzzin' with the hum of bees / The birds will make a racket in the churchyard trees / When I marry Mister Snow.
Oh, hello Enoch... this is how fireman carry people.
Where's the fire? I never thought I would see the woman I'm engaged to being carried out of the woods like a fallen deer.
He wasn't carrying me out of the woods, he was carrying me into the woods!
You'd think a woman with nine children would have more sense.
If I had more sense I wouldn't have had nine children.
I couldn't get work, and I couldn't bear to see her... to see her...
You couldn't bear to see her cry? Why don't you come right out and say it? Why are you ashamed you loved Julie?
I ain't afraid of anything. Look, if I can't go back, just say so.
I didn't say you couldn't go back.
No, but you didn't say I could, either. You're just trying to make me sweat.
No. I'm just trying to figure out what good you could do if I let you go back. You know... your daughter's down there. She's unhappy, she needs help.
My daughter? My baby is a girl? My-my baby's a girl?
She isn't a baby anymore. She's fifteen years old.
And she ain't happy, huh?
No, she ain't, Billy. You know, she's a lot like you. I think maybe that's why you could help her.
Can I see her from here?
Sure, you can, if you want to.
If she ain't happy, I don't want to look.
Right now, she appears to be having a fine time. There she is, running along the beach there, got her shoes and stockings off.
Like I used to do, huh?
Yeah. Do you want to take a look at her?
What do I have to do to see her?
Just look, and wait, and the power to see her will come to you.
To be perfectly honest with you...
I WOULD be, if I were you.
All right - I didn't mind livin' off her
[Julie's]
cousin Nettie. It was just having nothin' to do that drove me crazy.

[singing]
Stonecutters cut it on stone / Woodpeckers peck it on wood / There's nothin' so bad for a woman as a man who thinks he's good!
Yeah, I could still live here with Julie and...
Holy Moses!
Well, what's wrong?
Well, can you imagine how the girls'd love that, a barker who runs home to his wife every night! Why, people would laugh themselves sick! Well, I know I would!
[laughs]
Yeah, I can hear you laughing.
Don't be so stuck on yourself.

[greeting Billy for the first time]
Mr. Bigelow, I feel like I know you.
Ohhh, yes - the man who owns the herring boat. You smell it over there, Jigger?
Nope. Wind's in the wrong direction.
It's a good honest smell!
It's a powerful honest smell!

[to Mrs. Mullin]
Put on a new can of paint. You're startin' to peel, old pleasure-boat!
'Course, if you've got all the money you want, and you...
I ain't got a cent! Money thinks I'm dead.
[first lines]
Bigelow...

[impatiently]
Well, what'd I do now?
Nothing. I just thought you'd wanna know - there's trouble.
Huh! Thought you said I didn't do nothin'.
You being Julie's only kinfolk, I thought you oughta know. Ain't seen that barker from the carousel, neither.
If you ain't got any better than them...
Oh, I got better, I got better. Could be accidental, them both disappearin' at 't' same time. All the same, it does look a mite peculiar.
Nobody in our family ever did anythin' to be ashamed of, Clem Poops. Now you just find me a couple of good big lobsters or git!

[enters from a distance]
Cousin Nettie!
You're a funny kid. I don't remember ever meetin' a girl like you.
Hey! You tryin' to get me to marry ya?
No!
Well then what's puttin' it into my head?
I wonder what it'd be like?
If you loved me? But you don't.
No I don't.
